A 'pendulum' is a weight suspended from a so that it can swing
freely. {{cite encyclopedia
  | title = Pendulum encyclopedia = Miriam Webster's Collegiate Encyclopedia
  | volume = pages = 1241 publisher = Miriam Webster year = 2000 id = isbn = 0-87779-017-
  | 5 accessdate = }} When a pendulum is displaced sideways from its
  | resting equilibrium position, it is subject to a restoring force due to
  | gravity that will accelerate it back toward the equilibrium position. When
  | released, the restoring force combined with the pendulum's mass causes it to
  | oscillate about the equilibrium position, swinging back and forth. The time
  | for one complete cycle, a left swing and a right swing, is called the
  | period. A pendulum swings with a specific period which depends (mainly) on
  | its length.

From its discovery around 1602 by Galileo Galilei the regular motion of
pendulums was used for timekeeping, and was the world's most accurate
timekeeping technology until the 1930s. {{cite journal
|last=Marrison |first=Warren |title=The Evolution of the Quartz Crystal Clock
|journal=Bell System Technical Journal |year=1948 |volume=27 |pages=510â588 |url=http://www.ieee-
uffc.org/main/history.asp?file=marrison}} Pendulums are used to regulate
pendulum clocks, and are used in scientific instruments such as accelerometers
and seismometers. Historically they were used as gravimeters to measure the
acceleration of gravity in geophysical surveys, and even as a standard of
length. The word 'pendulum' is new Latin, from the Latin pendulus, meaning
'hanging'. {{cite book
  | last = Morris first = William, Ed. authorlink = coauthors = title =The
  | American Heritage Dictionary, New College Ed. publisher = Houghton-Mifflin
  | year = 1979 location = New York page = 969 url = doi = id = isbn = 0-395-20360-
  | 0}}

The 'simple gravity pendulum' defined by Christiaan Huygens: {{cite web
  | last = Huygens first = Christian authorlink = coauthors = title = Horologium
  | Oscillatorium work = [http://www.17centurymaths.com/ Some mathematical works
  | of the 17th and 18th centuries] publisher = 17thcenturymaths.com year = 1673
  | url = http://www.17centurymaths.com/contents/huygens/horologiumpart4a.pdf
  | format = PDF doi = accessdate = 2009-03-01}}, Part 4, Definition 3,
  | translated July 2007 by Ian Bruce is an idealized mathematical model
  | of a pendulum. {{cite web last = Nave first = Carl
  | R. authorlink = coauthors = title = Simple pendulum work = [http://hyperphysics.phy-
  | astr.gsu.edu/hbase/hph.html Hyperphysics] publisher = Georgia State Univ.
  | year = 2006 url = http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/pend.html doi =
  | accessdate = 2008-12-10}} {{cite web last = Xue first = Linwei
  | authorlink = coauthors = title = Pendulum Systems work = Seeing and Touching
  | Structural Concepts publisher = Civil Engineering Dept., Univ. of
  | Manchester, UK year = 2007 url = http://www.mace.manchester.ac.uk/project/t-
  | eaching/civil/structuralconcepts/Dynamics/pendulum/pendulum_con.php doi =
  | accessdate = 2008-12-10}} {{cite web last = Weisstein first = Eric
  | W. authorlink = coauthors = title = Simple Pendulum work = Eric Weisstein's
  | world of science publisher = [http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/ Wolfram
  | Research] year = 2007 url =
  | http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/SimplePendulum.html doi = accessdate
  | = 2009-03-09}} This is a weight (or bob) on the end of a massless cord
  | suspended from a , without friction. When given an initial push, it will
  | swing back and forth at a constant amplitude. Real pendulums are subject to
  | friction and air drag, so the amplitude of their swings declines.
